block.p: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.
Theater

CHAPPAQUA -- Chappaqua Drama Group presents ''The Miracle Worker'' by William Gibson. Today at 3 p.m., next Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $16; $14 for youths 13 through 18 and people 65 and older. Chappaqua Library, 195 South Greeley Avenue. 238-5003.

CROTON FALLS -- ''Abundance'' by Beth Henley. Next Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 4 p.m. Through June 11. Tickets: $17; $14 on Thursday evenings. The Schoolhouse, Owens Road. 277-8477.

ELMSFORD -- The musical ''Grease.'' Wednesdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m., with dinner at 6 and Sundays at 7 p.m., with dinner at 5. Matinees: Wednesdays and Thursdays at 1 p.m., with lunch at 11:30 a.m. and Sundays at 1:30 p.m., with lunch at noon. Through June 24. Tickets: $46 to $66, with discounts at selected performances for children, students and older people. Westchester Broadway Theater, 1 Broadway Plaza. 592-2222.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON -- The musical revue ''The World Goes Round -- The Songs of Kander and Ebb,'' performed by area youngsters. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $20; $10 for older people and children. Broadway Training Center of Westchester, 10 Washington Avenue. 478-5825.

IRVINGTON -- ''Madam C. J. Walker Speaks'' by Brenda Connor Bey and Veona Thomas. One-woman play starring Marilyn Anderson. Friday evening after a brief meeting of the Friends of the Irvington Library at 7:30 p.m. Free, including refreshments. Irvington Public Library, 12 South Astor Street. 591-9266.

IRVINGTON -- ''Sibling Revelry,'' starring Ann Hampton Callaway and Liz Callaway. Evening benefiting Hudson Stage Company. Host is Meredith Vieira of ''The View'' on ABC. Next Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $50 and $75, including reception after performance. (All but $10 tax deductible.) Irvington Town Hall Theater, 85 Main Street. 591-6602.

MOHEGAN LAKE -- Yorktown Community Players present ''Communicating Doors,'' comedy by Alan Ayckbourn. Today at 2 p.m. Tickets: $12; students and older people, $10; mothers, $6. Van Cortlandtville School, Route 6. 528-4145.
MONTROSE -- Auditions for Hand to Mouth Players July production of Neil Simon's ''Come Blow Your Horn.'' Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. Theater of Building 2, Veterans Affairs Hospital, Route 9A. 739-5902.
MOUNT VERNON -- ''Wine in the Wilderness'' by Alice Childress. Today at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15; students and older people, $8.50. Open Cage Theater, 326 South Third Avenue. 668-0814.

NEW ROCHELLE -- Premiere of Nelson Sheeley's ''...and call me in the morning''. Today at 2 p.m. Tickets: $25, with discounts for students and older people. Fleetwood Stage, 44 Wildcliff Drive. 654-8949.

PURCHASE -- ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' Today at 1 and 7 p.m. The musical ''The Little Prince,'' based on the book by Antoine de Saint-Exupery. Next Sunday at 1 and 7 p.m. Through May 28. Both presented by the Play Group Theater for Children and Young Adults. Tickets: $15; for students and older people, $12; children, $10. Little Theater of Manhattanville College. 946-0649.

SLEEPY HOLLOW -- ''The Fire This Time,'' re-enactment of an 18th-century trial of a slave accused of arson and conspiracy. Next Saturday 7 p.m. Tickets: $8; those 60 and older, $7; children 5 through 17, $4. Old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow. 631-8200, ext. 628.

YONKERS -- Actors Conservatory Theater presents the musical ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas.'' Today at 2 p.m., next Friday and Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $16; matinee performances, $14 for people 62 and older; advance tickets $1 less; dinner and show package, $33. Bryn Mawr Park Presbyterian Church, 20 Buckingham Road. 352-8307.
Music and Dance

ARMONK -- ''Fiddlers on Fire,'' bluegrass and swing fiddle favorites by Kenny Kosek, Bob Mastro and Travis Wetzel. Benefiting North Castle Public Library. Next Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15; children, $10. Whippoorwill Hall, Kent Place. 332-7780.

BEDFORD -- Charis Chamber Voices, performing Bach's ''Jesu, Meine Freude'' and Scarlatti's ''St. Cecelia Mass of 1720,'' with period instrumental accompaniment; Susan Peck, director. Next Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15; students and people 62 and older, $12. Bedford Presbyterian Church. 248-7113.

BEDFORD -- Empire Brass, performing brass quintet music ranging from Renaissance to Duke Ellington. Presented by Mount Kisco Concert Association. Next Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $25. Fox Lane High School, Route 172. 666-9181.

HARRISON -- Claude Frank, pianist, performing works by Schubert, Beethoven, Debussy and Chopin. Presented in private home by Performers of Westchester. Friday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $20. For further information, call 693-9658, evenings.

KATONAH -- Jennifer Frautschi and Laura Frautschi, violinists; Nicholas Cords and Kirsten Johnson, violists, and Edward Arron, cellist, performing works by Schubert, Ravel and Mendelssohn. Next Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15; members of Friends of Caramoor, $12. Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road. 232-1252.
LARCHMONT -- Students of Larchmont Music Academy performing classical, popular and jazz pieces. Thursday at 7:30 p.m. Free. Larchmont Public Library, 121 Larchmont Avenue. 834-2281.

MAMARONECK -- Iris Dement, vocalist. Thursday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $24; members, $15. Bob Paisley and the Southern Grass. Friday at 8:30 p.m., with ''pickin' party'' at 7:30. Tickets: $21; members, $15. ''Great Masters of the Millennium: Bach, Beethoven and Brahms, Part 3,'' concert featuring Paul Ostrovsky, pianist; Mark Peskanov, violinist; Daniel Panner, violist; and Eugene Osadchy, cellist. Next Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $30; members, $15; with cocktails and buffet dinner in a private home at 6 p.m., $100. Emelin Theater, Library Lane. 698-0098.

MOUNT KISCO -- Northern Westchester Symphony Orchestra performing works by Charles Lichter, Victor DeLisa and Schubert; guest conductor, Elliot Magaziner. Next Sunday at 3 p.m. $5 donation. Northern Westchester Center for the Arts, 272 North Bedford Rd. 241-6922.

MOUNT KISCO -- Claude Frank, pianist, performing works by Schubert, Beethoven, Debussy and Chopin. Presented in private home by Performers of Westchester. Next Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets: $20. For further information, call 693-9658, evenings.
NEW ROCHELLE -- Music, wine and cheese concert with Damocles Trio. Next Saturday at 3 p.m. $2 donation. New Rochelle Public Library, Library Plaza. 632-7878.

NEW ROCHELLE -- ''Spring Swing Thing!'' 20-voice Lance Hayward Singers performing arrangements by Mercer, Gershwin, Count Basie and others. Next Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $16; members, $14. Jewish Community Center of Mid-Westchester, 999 Wilmot Road. 472-3300, ext. 403.

PEEKSKILL -- ''East Meets West -- A Musical Montage,'' featuring Russian folk music by singers and musicians, Dan and Galla; excerpts from the Chinese opera ''The Monkey King'' with Qiao Li and classical music performed by Olga Diatchkovskaia, soprano; Sviatoslav Moroz, violinist; and Dmytri Rachmanov, pianist. Next Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $15; people 62 and older, $12; children, $8. Paramount Center, 1008 Brown St. 739-2333.
POCANTICO HILLS -- Organ recital by Judith Hancock. Next Saturday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $10. Union Church of Pocantico Hills, Route 448. 631-2069.

PURCHASE -- Purchase Youth Ballet open house, with presentation of works coached by ballerina, Valentina Kozlova. Tuesday at 5:30 p.m. Free. Reservations. Conservatory of Dance. 725-8754. Andre Watts, pianist, performing works by Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert and Chopin. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $42. Performing Arts Center. 251-6200. ''Sex, Love and Barber,'' Westchester Philharmonic, with violinist, Pamela Frank, in a program of Tchaikowsky, Liszt, Bartok and Barber; Paul Lustig Dunkel, conductor. Next Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 3 p.m., with June LeBell interviewing Ms. Frank at 1:45. Tickets: $29 to $39. (Open rehearsal, next Saturday 10 a.m. Tickets: $3.) Performing Arts Center. 682-3707, ext. 10. Purchase College.

SCARSDALE -- Guest soloists, orchestra and full parish choir performing works by Mozart, Handel and others. Presented in celebration of church's 150th anniversary. Next Sunday at 4 p.m. Tickets: $30; advance tickets, $25. Church of St. James the Less, Church Lane at Crane Road. 723-6100.

WHITE PLAINS -- Linda Betjeman, organist, in a program of music by Anders Ohrwall, Kendell R. B. Kardt and others. Wednesday at 12:35 p.m. Tickets: $5. Grace Episcopal Church, Main Street and Mamaroneck Ave. 949-0394.

WHITE PLAINS -- New York Cabaret Unlimited performing Broadway favorites by Frank Loesser, including music from ''Guys and Dolls'' and ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.'' Next Saturday at 8 p.m. Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, 7 Saxon Wood Road. 948-1120.
YONKERS -- Yonkers Male Glee Club singing Broadway favorites, popular standards and American classics. Next Saturday at 2 p.m. Free. Will Library, 1500 Central Park Avenue. 337-1500.
Art
DOBBS FERRY -- Exhibition of works by gallery artists. Reception today from 2 to 5 p.m. Through June 4. Upstream Gallery, 26B Main Street. 674-8548.
DOBBS FERRY -- ''Travels and Inspirations,'' landscapes and still lifes by Angela Stratton. Through June. Reception next Saturday from 1 to 4 p.m. Forever Gallery, 60 Cedar Street. 674-8035.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON -- ''Collection of Art Celebrating Our Native American Heritage,'' featuring jewelry, kachinas, baskets, beaded works and artifacts. Opening receptions next Saturday and Sunday from noon to 5 p.m. Through August. Arctic Artistry, 2 Spring Street. 478-7179.
KATONAH -- ''Color Energies,'' show by members of Northern Westchester Watercolor Society. Through next Saturday. Katonah Village Library, 26 Bedford Road. 232-3508.

NORTH SALEM -- ''Unbottled: New York's Water: Conservation + Preservation + Inspiration,'' an exhibition exploring contemporary landscape issues in art and science in the county; including water purity, animal protection, wetlands and history of the Croton Reservoir and watershed area. Museum hours: Wednesdays through Saturdays from noon to 4 p.m. (Lunch available by reservation, beginning Wednesday. 669-6777). Hammond Museum and Japanese Stroll Garden, top of Deveau Road, off June Road. 669-5033.
PEEKSKILL -- ''People and Places,'' drawings and paintings by Neva T. Savath. Through May. Reception next Saturday from 1 to 5 p.m. Flat Iron Gallery, 105 South Division Street. 734-1894.

PEEKSKILL -- ''Landscapes and River Views of the Hudson Valley'' by Susan Basile, John Henry, Susan Obrant and six other artists. Through June 4. Reception next Saturday from 3 to 7 p.m. Upper View Gallery, 6 North Division Street. 739-3530.

PEEKSKILL -- Walking tour of artists' galleries, studios and residences, led by Wendie Garber. Next Saturday from 10 a.m. to noon. Tickets: $5. Meet in front of Paramount Center, 1008 Brown Street. 734-1894.

POUND RIDGE -- ''Paint and Light,'' works by Elizabeth Castellano, Elizabeth La Bella and Lisa Mancini. Through May 27. Reception next Saturday from noon to 2 p.m. Hiram Halle Memorial Library. 764-5085.

PURCHASE -- ''Welded! Sculpture of the 20th Century'' and ''Portraits of the Artists as Young Girls,'' an installation by Carol Hamoy. Open today. Continuing: ''Whitfield Lovell: Portrayals,'' ''Recent Acquisitions: Selections From the Lawrence Gussman Collection of African Art,'' ''Selections From the Roy R. Neuberger Collection,'' ''Object and Intellect: African Art From the Permanent Collection'' and ''Ancient Civilizations: The Roy R. Neuberger Collection.'' Museum's hours: Tuesdays through Fridays 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Saturdays and Sundays 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; students and people 62 and older, $2; free for children. Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase College. 251-6100.
PURCHASE -- Alumni art exhibition, featuring works by 34 artists. Through June 19. Library of Manhattanville College. 694-2200.
SCARSDALE -- Paintings and works on paper by 20 contemporary artists. Through May 31. Madelyn Jordon Fine Art, 4 Depot Place. 262-5764.
VALHALLA -- Prints, drawings, paintings and sculpture by art students. Through May 23. Temporary art gallery of Westchester Community College. 785-6700.
WHITE PLAINS -- Hand-illuminated books and calligraphy by Karen Gorst. Through May. Adult alcove, White Plains Public Library, 100 Martine Ave. 422-1480.
Lectures
HARRISON -- ''Women and Depression'' by Dr. Arlene Hysman. Wednesday at 7:30 to 8:30 p.m. Free. Conference center of Saint Vincents. 967-6500.

HARRISON -- ''Bags Out at Seven: A Tale of Too Many Cities,'' Robert Globerman talks of the marvels and problems he has encountered. Wednesday at 8 p.m. Free. Harrison Public Library, Bruce Avenue. 835-0324.
KATONAH -- ''Oppositional Youth: How to Counsel, Teach and Parent'' by Dr. Frank Doberman. Friday at 9:30 to 11 a.m. Free. Conference center of Four Winds, 800 Cross River Rd. 763-8151, ext. 2413.

MOUNT KISCO -- Poetry reading by Daniel Moran. Followed by open mike. Tomorrow 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $7; students and people 62 and older, $5. Creative Arts Cafe, Northern Westchester Center for the Arts, 272 North Bedford Rd. 241-6922.
NEW ROCHELLE -- ''Caring for Arthritis Naturally'' by Scott Cohen, chiropractor. Friday at 1 p.m. Free. New Rochelle Public Library. 632-7878.
RYE -- ''19th-Century Clothing'' by Kathy Maher. Tuesday from noon to 1 p.m. Free. Bring bag lunch. Rye Historical Society's Square House Museum, 1 Purchase Street. 967-7588.

SCARSDALE -- ''Not Just Music and Sports: African-American Legacy in Literature, History, Medicine and Science,'' symposium presented in conjunction with the current exhibition ''The Real McCoy: A Legacy of African-American Inventors and Innovators.'' Next Saturday 9 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $60, including box lunch. Scarsdale Historical Society Museum, 937 White Plains Post Road. 723-1744.

TARRYTOWN -- Reading by Rick Moody, author of ''Purple America'' and ''The Ice Storm.'' Next Saturday at 7 p.m., with picnicking from 5:30 p.m. Tickets: $12; members of Hudson Valley Writers Center and members of Historic Hudson Valley, $10. Sunnyside, off Route 9. 631-8200, ext. 628.

WHITE PLAINS -- Powers of attorney, living wills and health care proxies are discussed by lawyers, Kathy N. Rosenthal and Frederick C. Weit. Presented by the Arthritis Foundation, Hudson Valley Branch. Wednesday from 1 to 3 p.m. Free. Burke House, Burke Rehabilitation Hospital. 683-0842.
WHITE PLAINS -- Haiti's heritage is illustrated through its art. Program presented by Haitian Heritage Group of White Plains. Next Saturday at 2 p.m. Free. White Plains Public Library. 422-1480.

WHITE PLAINS -- Ethics and the news media are discussed by Joseph Berger of The New York Times and Meryl Harris of The Journal News. Next Sunday at 10:30 a.m. Ethical Culture Society of Westchester, 7 Saxon Wood Road. 948-1120.

YONKERS -- Jay Williams debates Ted Debiak on controversial ideas about the nature of motion in animals and plants. Presented by New York Area Skeptics. Wednesday at 7 p.m. Free. Will Library. 699-9124.

YONKERS -- Panel discussion on kayaking and canoeing on the Hudson River. Topics include camping areas and access sites. Friday at 7:30 p.m. Beczak Environmental Education Center, 21 Alexander Street. 376-0859.
Films
PEEKSKILL -- ''Not One Less,'' Chinese film with subtitles. Thursday through next Saturday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $9. Paramount Center. 739-2333.
VALHALLA -- ''After Life,'' Japanese film with subtitles. Friday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $6; people 60 and older, $5. Academic Arts Theater, Westchester Community College. 785-6700.
WHITE PLAINS -- ''I Don't Want to Talk About It,'' Spanish film with subtitles, starring Marcello Mastroianni. Tomorrow at 2 p.m. Free. White Plains Public Library. 422-1480.
Children

ARMONK -- ''Circus in a Suitcase,'' show combines acrobatics, juggling and clowning. Presented by Playtime Productions. Next Saturday at 1:30 p.m. Tickets: $9; advance tickets, $8. North Castle Library, 19 Whippoorwill Road East. 674-0906.

KATONAH -- Dog show, with prizes for the best dressed, biggest ears, best personality and other categories. Bring photograph of yourself with your dog. Next Sunday at 3 p.m. Cost: $2. Katonah Museum of Art, Route 22 and Jay Street. 232-9555.
MAMARONECK -- ''Wizard of Oz,'' children's show. Next Saturday at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m. Tickets: $12; family members, $8. Emelin Theater. 698-0098.

NEW ROCHELLE -- Mad Hatter tea party. For children 3 through 10 and accompanying adult. Featuring a magician, juggler, storytellers and marionette show. Next Sunday from 1 to 3 p.m. Tickets: $10; accompanying adults, $5. Reservations. New Rochelle Public Library. 632-7878, ext. 16.

SLEEPY HOLLOW -- Pinkster festival with music, Colonial dancing, trickster tales, musical instrument demonstrations, children's games, visits to farm animals and the sale of African and Colonial foods and picnic fare. Next Saturday and Sunday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tickets: $8; people 60 and older, $7; children 6 through 17, $5; younger children, free. Philipsburg Manor, Route 9. 631-3992.
SOMERS -- Children 4 and older make grapevine wreaths and greeting cards for their mothers. Today from noon to 3 p.m. Free. Muscoot Farm, Route 100. 232-7118.
TARRYTOWN -- ''Peter Pan,'' show by Theaterworks U.S.A. Friday at 10 a.m. Tickets: $9. Music Hall Theater, 13 Main Street. 631-3390.

YONKERS -- Children make scented sachets for their mothers. Today at 1:30 p.m. Admission: $1 and museum admission additional $4; people 62 and older and children, $3. The planetarium show ''The Sky Tonight.'' Friday at 7 p.m. Free. Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Avenue. 963-4550.
YONKERS -- Learn about river ecology while helping to pull in river critters with a giant seining net. Today from 1 to 3 p.m. Beczak Environmental Education Center. 376-0859.

YONKERS -- Introduction to live wild animals. Program for all ages, presented by a naturalist from the Theodore Roosevelt Audubon Sanctuary. Next Saturday at 2 p.m. Free. Lenoir Nature Preserve. 237-9331.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS -- ''Community Care Day,'' with children's games, soccer clinic, pony rides, refreshments and craft workshops. Next Saturday from noon to 5 p.m. Downing Park. (Rain location, Mildred Strang Middle School). 243-8170.
Potpourri

ARMONK -- Open house at Amawalk Meeting House, with tours and refreshments. Sponsored by Yorktown Historical Society. Next Saturday from 1 to 4 p.m., with illustrated lecture on its history and scheduled restoration, by architect, Charles H. Henkels, at 2 p.m. Free. 2467 Quaker Church Road. 962-3045.
GREENBURGH -- Open house, with programs and refreshments. Next Saturday from 2 to 4 p.m. Free. Greenburgh Nature Center, Dromore Road. 723-3470.

TARRYTOWN -- ''Spring Crafts at Lyndhurst,'' featuring 325 craft artists. Next Friday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. and next Saturday 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Through next Sunday. Tickets: $8; people 60 and older, $7; children 6 through 16, $4. Lyndhurst, 635 South Broadway. 631-4481.
WHITE PLAINS -- Woodcutting and printing techniques workshop, led by Campbell Geeslin. Thursday at 7 and (repeated) next Saturday at 2 p.m. Free. Registration. White Plains Public Library. 422-1480.
YONKERS -- Used book sale, with books priced at 50 cents a pound. Next Saturday from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. and next Sunday noon to 3 p.m. Will Library. 337-1500.
YONKERS -- Greek-American Culture Day, with performances, crafts and refreshments. Next Saturday from 2 to 5 p.m. Lincoln Park. 966-1219.
